text:
Julia doesn’t have a indentation convention.
This is actually the key point where BlueStyle and YASGuide diverge.
Though neither want quite what haskell does

Approximately:
*BlueStyle* says: Always indent 4 spaces. Always
*YASGuide* says: Indent with 4 spaces, except If an argument list extends to multiple lines, in that case align new lines to the parenthesis/bracket/etc. that started the argument list.

text:
Consider this code
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/5ee2d601edcf2dcdd467041ba9f08c43bf23e1a3/base/arrayshow.jl#L137-L139>

```r = k == length(A) && !pad_right ?
    "" :
    repeat(" ", max(0, w-length(vdots)-length(l)))```
(Which both BlueStyle and YASGuide say is correctly indented)


Following the Haskell rules it would be something like:
```r = k == length(A) && !pad_right ?
                        "" :
                        repeat(" ", max(0, w-length(vdots)-length(l)))```
Which is way worse. (IMO)

text:
I can get behind the YASGuide aligning arguments.
(I have some pros and cons of it, but I could happily use it).
I can’t get behind the haskell one, as it basically maximises the chance to get into pathological cases where your code is squeezed up against the right margin.
(Or off screen if you don’t enforce a line limit)
